doc:section.name: introduction
doc:section.p: RabbitMQ comes with default built-in settings which will most likely be sufficient for running your RabbitMQ server effectively. If it runs fine, then you probably don't need any configuration at all.

If you have other constraints, RabbitMQ provides two general ways to customise the server:
environment variables
define ports, file locations and names (taken from the shell, or set in the rabbitmq-env.conf file)
a configuration file
defines server component settings for permissions, limits and clusters, and also plugin settings.

doc:subsection.name: verify-configuration
doc:subsection.doc:heading: Verify Configuration

doc:subsection.name: customise-general-unix-environment
doc:subsection.doc:heading: Unix (general)
doc:subsection.p: On Unix-based systems (including Linux, MacOSX) you can create/edit rabbitmq-env.conf to define environment variables. Its location is not configurable (unlike rabbitmq.config, which is by default in the same directory).

Use the standard environment variable names (but drop the RABBITMQ_ prefix) e.g.
#example rabbitmq-env.conf file entries #Rename the node NODENAME=bunny #Config file location and new filename bunnies.config CONFIG_FILE=/etc/rabbitmq/testdir/bunnies More info on using rabbitmq-env.conf

doc:subsection.name: customise-windows-environment
doc:subsection.doc:heading: Windows
doc:subsection.p: If you need to customise names, ports, locations, it is easiest to configure environment variables in the Windows dialogue: Start > Settings > Control Panel > System > Advanced > Environment Variables.
Create or edit the system variable name and value. For environment changes to take effect, open a new Command Prompt, then restart the broker or re-install the service.

doc:section.name: define-environment-variables
doc:section.doc:heading: RabbitMQ Environment Variables
doc:section.p: RabbitMQ environment variable names have the prefix RABBITMQ_.

p.p: In this way, variables set in the shell environment take priority over variables set in rabbitmq-env.conf, which in turn over-ride RabbitMQ built-in defaults.

doc:section.p: It is unlikely you will need to set any of these environment variables. If you have non-standard requirements, then RabbitMQ environment variables include, but are not limited to:
doc:section.div:
NameDefaultDescription
RABBITMQ_NODE_IP_ADDRESS the empty string - meaning bind to all network interfaces. Change this if you only want to bind to one network interface.
RABBITMQ_NODE_PORT 5672
RABBITMQ_BASE Windows: %APPDATA%\RabbitMQ
This base directory contains sub-directories for the RabbitMQ server's database and log files. Alternatively, set RABBITMQ_MNESIA_BASE and RABBITMQ_LOG_BASE individually.
RABBITMQ_NODENAME
Unix*: rabbit@$HOSTNAME
Windows: rabbit@%COMPUTERNAME%
The node name should be unique per erlang-node-and-machine combination. To run multiple nodes, see the clustering guide.
RABBITMQ_CONFIG_FILE
Unix*: /etc/rabbitmq/rabbitmq
Windows: %RABBITMQ_BASE%\rabbitmq
If the configuration file is present it is used by the server to configure RabbitMQ components. The .config extension is automatically appended by the Erlang runtime. This file is also used to auto-configure RabbitMQ clusters.
RABBITMQ_MNESIA_BASE
Unix*: /var/lib/rabbitmq/mnesia
Windows: %RABBITMQ_BASE%\db
This base directory contains sub-directories for the RabbitMQ server's Mnesia database files, one for each node, unless RABBITMQ_MNESIA_DIR is set explicitly.
RABBITMQ_MNESIA_DIR
Unix*: $RABBITMQ_MNESIA_BASE/$RABBITMQ_NODENAME
Windows: %RABBITMQ_MNESIA_BASE%\%RABBITMQ_NODENAME%
The directory where this RabbitMQ node's Mnesia database files are placed.
RABBITMQ_LOG_BASE
Unix*: /var/log/rabbitmq
Windows: %RABBITMQ_BASE%\log
This base directory contains the RabbitMQ server's log files, unless RABBITMQ_LOGS or RABBITMQ_SASL_LOGS are set explicitly.
RABBITMQ_LOGS
Unix*: $RABBITMQ_LOG_BASE/$RABBITMQ_NODENAME.log
Windows: %RABBITMQ_LOG_BASE%\%RABBITMQ_NODENAME%.log
The path of the RabbitMQ server's Erlang log file. This variable cannot be overridden in Windows.
RABBITMQ_SASL_LOGS
Unix*: $RABBITMQ_LOG_BASE/$RABBITMQ_NODENAME-sasl.log
Windows: %RABBITMQ_LOG_BASE%\%RABBITMQ_NODENAME%-sasl.log
The path of the RabbitMQ server's Erlang SASL (System Application Support Libraries) log file. This variable cannot be overridden in Windows.
RABBITMQ_PLUGINS_DIR
Unix*: $RABBITMQ_HOME/plugins
Windows: Installation-directory/plugins
The directory in which the plugins are found. This variable cannot be overridden on Windows.
RABBITMQ_PLUGINS_EXPAND_DIR
Unix*: $RABBITMQ_MNESIA_BASE/$RABBITMQ_NODENAME-plugins-expand
Windows: %RABBITMQ_MNESIA_BASE%\%RABBITMQ_NODENAME%-plugins-expand
Working directory used to expand enabled plugins when starting the server.
RABBITMQ_ENABLED_PLUGINS_FILE
Unix*: /etc/rabbitmq/enabled_plugins
Windows: %RABBITMQ_BASE%\enabled_plugins
This file records explicitly enabled plugins.
RABBITMQ_SERVICENAME Windows Service: RabbitMQ
The name of the installed service. This will appear in services.msc.
RABBITMQ_CONSOLE_LOG Windows Service:
Set this variable to new or reuse to redirect console output from the server to a file named %RABBITMQ_SERVICENAME%.debug in the default RABBITMQ_BASE directory.
If not set, console output from the server will be discarded (default).
new A new file will be created each time the service starts.
reuse The file will be overwritten each time the service starts.
RABBITMQ_SERVER_ERL_ARGS
Unix*: "+K true +A30 +P 1048576 -kernel inet_default_connect_options [{nodelay,true}]"
Windows: None
Standard parameters for the erl command used when invoking the RabbitMQ Server. This should be overridden for debugging purposes only.
RABBITMQ_SERVER_START_ARGS None
Extra parameters for the erl command used when invoking the RabbitMQ Server. This will not override RABBITMQ_SERVER_ERL_ARGS.
RABBITMQ_PID_FILE
Unix*: $RABBITMQ_MNESIA_DIR.pid
File in which the process id is placed for use by rabbitmqctl wait.
* Unix, Linux, MacOSX
Paths are given relative to the installation directory prefix. For example Mac OSX (macports) are normally based in /opt/local/, or /usr/local on Mac OSX (homebrew) and some BSD installations.
Other variables upon which RabbitMQ depends are:
NameDefaultDescription
HOSTNAME
Unix, Linux: `env hostname`
MacOSX: `env hostname -s`
The name of the current machine
COMPUTERNAME Windows: localhost The name of the current machine
ERLANG_SERVICE_MANAGER_PATH Windows Service:
%ERLANG_HOME%\erts-x.x.x\bin
This path is the location of erlsrv.exe, the Erlang service wrapper script.

doc:subsection.name: config-file
doc:subsection.doc:heading: The rabbitmq.config File
doc:subsection.p: The configuration file rabbitmq.config allows the RabbitMQ core application, Erlang services and RabbitMQ plugins to be configured. It is a standard Erlang configuration file, documented on the Erlang Config Man Page.
This example will alter the dump_log_write_threshold for mnesia (increasing from the default of 100), and alter the port RabbitMQ listens on from 5672 to 5673.

This configuration file is not the same as rabbitmq-env.conf, which can be used to set environment variables on non-windows systems. A future release of RabbitMQ will unify the two configuration mechanisms.

doc:subsection.name: config-location
doc:subsection.doc:heading: Location of rabbitmq.config and rabbitmq-env.conf
doc:subsection.p:
The location of these files is distribution-specific. By default, they are not created, but expect to be located in the following places on each platform:
Generic UNIX - /etc/rabbitmq/
Debian - /etc/rabbitmq/
RPM - /etc/rabbitmq/
Mac OS X (Macports) - /opt/local/etc/rabbitmq/
Windows - %APPDATA%\RabbitMQ\
If rabbitmq-env.conf doesn't exist, it can be created manually in the default location only. It is not used on Windows systems.

If rabbitmq.config doesn't exist, it can be created manually. Set the RABBITMQ_CONFIG_FILE environment variable if you change the location. The Erlang runtime automatically appends the .config extension to the value of this variable.
Restart the server after changes. Windows service users need to take additional steps when changing plugins.

doc:subsection.name: config-items
doc:subsection.doc:heading: Variables Configurable in rabbitmq.config
doc:subsection.p: Many users of RabbitMQ never need to change any of these values, and some are fairly obscure. However, for completeness they are all listed here.

tr.td: List of ports on which to listen for AMQP connections (without SSL). Can contain integers (meaning "listen on all interfaces") or tuples such as {"127.0.0.1", 5672} to listen on a single interface.
As above, for SSL connections.
SSL configuration. See the SSL documentation.
Memory threshold at which the flow control is triggered. See the memory-based flow control documentation.

Controls the granularity of logging. The value is a list of log event category and log level pairs.
The level can be one of 'none' (no events are logged), 'error' (only errors are logged), 'warning' (only errors and warning are logged), or 'info' (errors, warnings and informational messages are logged).
At present there is just one category defined - 'connection', for all events relating to network connections. Other, currently uncategorised, events are always logged.

Maximum permissible size of a frame (in bytes) to negotiate with clients. Setting to 0 means "unlimited" but will trigger a bug in some QPid clients. Setting a larger value may improve throughput; setting a smaller value may improve latency.
Virtual host to create when RabbitMQ creates a new database from scratch. The exchange amq.rabbitmq.log will exist in this virtual host.
User name to create when RabbitMQ creates a new database from scratch.
Password for the default user.
Tags for the default user.
Permissions to assign to the default user when creating it.
Set this to cause clustering to happen automatically.
List of key-value pairs to announce to clients on connection.

Statistics collection mode. Primarily relevant for the management plugin. Options are:
none (do not emit statistics events)
coarse (emit per-queue / per-channel / per-connection statistics)
fine (also emit per-message statistics)
You probably don't want to change this yourself.
Statistics collection interval in milliseconds. Primarily relevant for the management plugin.
SASL authentication mechanisms to offer to clients.
List of authentication databases to use. Other databases than rabbit_auth_backend_internal are available through plugins.
Number of delegate processes to use for intra-cluster communication. On a machine which has a very large number of cores and is also part of a cluster, you may wish to increase this value.
Used internally by the tracer. You shouldn't change this.
Default socket options. You probably don't want to change this.

Set to true to precompile parts of RabbitMQ with the High Performance Erlang compiler. This will increase the message rate that the server can handle, while also increasing startup time.
You might see 20-50% better performance at the cost of approximately 1 minute delay at startup. These figures are highly workload- and hardware-dependent.
HiPE support may not be compiled into your Erlang installation. If it is not, enabling this option will just cause a warning message to be displayed and startup will proceed as normal. For example, Debian / Ubuntu users will need to install the erlang-base-hipe package.
HiPE is not available at all on some platforms, notably including Windows.
This option should be considered experimental. If your Erlang VM segfaults, disable this option again.
Implementation module for queue indexing. You probably don't want to change this.
Implementation module for queue contents. You probably don't want to change this.
Tunable value for the persister. You almost certainly should not change this.
Tunable value for the persister. You almost certainly should not change this.

doc:subsection.p: In addition, many plugins can have sections in the configuration file, with names of the form rabbitmq_plugin. Our maintained plugins are documented in the following locations:
